data.text: @BenK78457034 @EricTopol Early data suggests this is not true. In the Nature study  even mild cases showed brain lesions. We have no data indicating therapeutics stop the longterm damage to organs. Science will get us there, in the meantime we should minimize transmission.
@218res1 @EricTopol Once you have it once it is mild once you get it again. The arguments you are making are moot since so many have been infected and paxlovid is now reasonably available

@BenK78457034 @EricTopol If this were a mild disease, I could agree. This virus is continuing to kill thousands and causing serious longterm illness in many. the study in Nature this week  should give us pause about allowing infection in children.
@218res1 @EricTopol At the population level this is correct mostly because little kids would get infected. Most diseases we get once we are infected we are immune for life or close to immune for life

@BenK78457034 @EricTopol immunity has not happened without mass vaccination for many diseases. too many mutations. this is looking like one of those. plus the morbidity and mortality cost is too high. need to mitigate and eradicate..
@218res1 @EricTopol We likely won't need to use any indicators lagging or not... That's what immunity does at least at a societal level
@catameep @EricTopol It likely actually is lower due to the fact we have more infection based immunity. At least for this very moment
